Nebraska Agricultural Statistics 1929 ISSUED COOPERATIVELY BY United States Department of Agriculture Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates AND Nebraska State Department of Agriculture Division of Agricultural Statistics h. j. Mclaughlin Secretary of Agriculture . Compiled by A. E. ANDERSON, State and Federal Statistician E. V. JONES, Asst. Statistician LINCOLN, NEBRASKA THE CLAFLIN PRINTING CO.. LINCOLN. NEOR.
SNAKE RIVER FALLS, CHERRY COUNTY (Courtesy, State Publicity Dept.)

To His Excellency ; . HON. ARTHUIt J. WEAVER, Governor ot Nebraska. Development m the work of gathering agricultural statistics lias been wade, principally, along three lines. First, special endeavor was made to get a more complete annual census of agriculture through the assessors. Second, greater publicity on the statistics of agricul - ture that are helprul to the farmer. Third, more educational work on the value of statlt - tica through the press, by public address and m the schools. A rather marked improvement m the quality and completeness of the work done by precinct assessors m gathering the annual statistics on acreage plumed and upon livestock is noted. The work is bnsic and essuutinl to accurate statistics. No other state can boast of a better developed system of guthernlg statistics through the assessors, and much of the credit for the success ot this work Is due- to the efforts of our precinct assessors. The maximum value ot agricultural statistics can not be obtained without the publica - tion of the material gathered. In this age of keen competlton nut only among, our six and. a half million farmers m this country but also among the nations of the world for the con-' suming markets of agricultural products, it Is essential that farmers look into the future and plan their production m the light ot statistical facts m the same manner as those en - gaged m other industry. . The federal government realizes this and is now establishing twelve foreign offices throughout the world to gather Information on the world supply and demand for agricul - tural products. With such world wide information It will be able to make plans for the future course of agricultural production. Other Industries cannot endure under the policy of blind production, nor can agriculture make its maximum advancement under such & . system. Tho gathering of morn statistical information as a guide to the future course of agri - culture so that remedial measures can be proposed and enacted and further effort to en - courage farmers to make practical use of such information Is now receiving more than usual attention from the Division of Agricultural Statistics. Demand has been made to place this Issue of Nebraska. Agricultural Statistics In every rural school In the state as well as m all high schools bo that it may be studied m connection with courses In agricul - ture offered. Nebraska's basic and lending industry Is agriculture. The gross cash fnrm income tor the year ending Jinn- 30, 1929, is $496,058,000. -Latest figures on the second industry, manu - facturing, are $420,000,000. Agriculture contributed the raw material for $290,310,000 worth of the manufactured products or over 70%. as follows: meat packing. $t53,271.000; butter, $44,740,000; sugar, $14,700,000; bread and bakery products, $13,124,000; Hour and feed pro - ducts, $30,303,000; others. $10,181,000. Apparently, most of the publicity which has for its purpose the advertising of the possibilities of the state with a view ot encouraging people to come to Nebraska, must be derived from tin- basic facts gathered by the Division ot Agricultural Statistics. The 1929 production of crops, taken as a whole was slightly above the average. Bar - ley,- sugar beets, sweet clover and llnx made new high records. Market receipts of cattle were slightly less than m 1928 but more hoirs.and sheep were marketed. Tlier? was n slight increase m butterfnt sold. Nebraska fared better than other states In production last year. Her high rank m production last year was raised In, all wheat, oats, barley, flax, potatoes, apples, tame hay, milk cows and sheep; it was maintained In corn, winter wheat, rye. grain sorghum, sugar beets, wild hay, alfalfa, horses, mules, other cattle and swine, anil only In spring/wheat and all hay was the rank lower. The chief drawback to agriculture is the price disparity with the products of ofher Industries. The first six or eight months of the year were favorable to agriculture since the level of prices had raised until the ratio of prices received by farmers to prices paid, stood at 02 which had not been exceeded for any year since the farm price dellatlon m 1920. This Index had dropped to SO at the close of the year and to S2 by March 1, 1930. The previous low points were 75 m 1921 nnd 81 m 1922. The progress that agriculture had made toward parity m price with other industry during the past decade was nenrly wiped out m a period of six months. Economical production and planning future action m the light of past records of pro - duction and future demand is the keynote for recovery of agriculture. Agriculture must bo able to look forward through statistical facts as well as backward for a solution of ita problems. Any action taken to help the Industry will have to be based upon the cold facts as to the situation of agriculture as shown by the statistics. Respectfully, h. j. Mclaughlin, Secretary of Agriculture. • 3

IN BILLIONS OF POUNDS THE SUPPLY OF POKK IS THE LARGEST PRICE DETERMINING FACTOR Contrary to the belief of some farmers, the supply of port largely determines the price of hogs rather than alleged packer manipulation. The demand for pork exerts an influence also and the combined effects of these two factors makes the price of hogs. The above chart oilers quite conclusive evidence as to this fact. By studying this chart, you will observe for the hog crop year, 1925-26 the packers received ■lightly more than 9,500,000,000 pounds of live hogs. (Run a line down from the dot of 1925-26 production perpendicular to the base or lower horizontal line upon which the graduations of live hogs purchased is given m billions of pounds. This indicates slightly more than 9,500,000,000 pounds of live hogs. Run another line from this dot horizontally to the left price line. This indicates slightly more than $12 per .100 pounds paid for hogs.) Next, observe the dot indicat - ing 1923-24 production and price. Note the slaughter was high, nearly 12,000,000,000 pounds and the price was below $8 per 100 pounds. • ; . The heavy diagonal line represents the average price for a given- production for the period of time Included m this chart, 1922 to 1928. Had the demand been constant, it is highly prob - able all of the dots would hnve fallen on the line. Among other things, the demand is affected by competitive meats such as beef, mutton and poultry, by business conditions which affect the buying power of consumers, condition of employment, etc. However, the lesson to be learned is that supply is the leading factor determining price and except for slight variations m demand, it is almost directly proportional to the supply. CAN FARMERS ADJUST THE SUPPLY OF HOGS TO BRING A SATISFACTORY PRICE? It ib possible for farmers to adjust the supply of hogs to the demand to a very marked ex - tent and to obtain more satisfactory prices. It cannot be done undsr the haphazard method of blind production whereby farmers breed more sows when the price is high and less sows when the price is low. Past records show this method has "resulted m four or five year hog cycles, 2Vi years of descending and 2'j years of ascending price. This is brought about from the fact that when production is high and prices low, the farmer breeds less sows.' Soon he finds production . low and prices high and he begins to increase breeding. By the time he Bets the production up again, the prices arc low and so on through the next cycle. Fortunately, it is within the power of farmers to correct this situation to a large extent. The solution to this problem of maintaining steady and maximum price is largely m adjustment of production which can be accomplished by the pig surveys. The June pig survey gives the size . of the spring pig crop as compared with past years. The farmer can determine whether produc - tion is high, low or normal. The survey also gives the plans for breeding for the fall pie crop. The farmer therefore has the necessary information to adjust- the supply. The December pig survey gives the information on the siie- of the fall pig crop and, the breeding intentions for the spring crop. (Please turn to page 31 for additional explanation as to the use and value of Die surveys.) 14

AUUSTCO rON TWH O ANO If M FMCt IXVIL PRICE PAJO BY PACKERS ' ; __^_ DOLLARS [ PER 100 Vw POUNDS '28 9 - — — -S^L, ; X i i 'i i ~ i i i i i i i i I i i i i 8.0 85 aO 9.5 10.0 LIVE WEIGHT OF SLAUGHTER IN BILLION S OF POUNDS THE SUPPLY OF BEEF DETERMINES LARGELY THE PRICE A rather definite relationship between supply and demand of beef exists as manifested by the above chart. The base or bottom line gives the quantity ot beet slaughtered m billions of pounds under federal inspection. The figures ut the left give the price m dollars per hundred pounds of beef. The quantity slaughtered and the price paid for bsef cattle are given for the years, 1922 to 1928, inclusive. The diagonal line between 'the dots represents the average re - lationship between the price and the supply and. demand. Observe that m 1928 when the supply had fallen to nearly 8,000,000,000 lbs. that the price exceeded $9 per hundred pounds. The low point m price during this period was reached In 1926 when the supply was nearly 10,000,000,000 lbs., resulting m a price below 57 per hundred pounds. Apparently the supply is the leading factor affecting price. The demand is affected by competition from pork, mutton, poultry, employment and business conditions. CATTLE SUPPLY CAN BE ADJUSTED TO STABILIZE PRICE Fast records show that cattle production runs m cycles of 12 to 15 years duration, or about three times that of .the hog production cycle. The cause of these cycles is the trend m price to which production- responds as m the case of hogs. The response of production to price naturally takes much more time for cattle than for hogs or sheep. Cattle production is a long time enter - prise. When the low point m production is reached, the price of cattle is high. High price stimulates production. Increased production calls for increased breeding stock. One season is necessary for gestation to produce a heifer calf, and nearly two years more for this calf to ' reach breeding ace. Add to this about three more years to raise and fatten a steer, making a total of six years to increase production. By this time prices will have reached the peak or high point. In the meantime farmers continue to save heifer calves for breeding not only during the period of high prices but for two or three years after production reaches a high point that causes declining prices and finally production follows. Reduced production again stimulates price and another cattle production cycle begins. ; Cattle production cycles usually last 15 years. There was a high point m production m 1892-93 ; 190-1-05 ; 1919-20. Low points of production were reached m 1897, 1912 and 1928. At present, cattle are on an increasing production point of the cycle with decreasing price. The war demand for beet made the last upward swing m cattle production rather marked. Not only will this factor be lacking m the present upward swing of cattle production, but sheep have re - placed cattle on part of the ranee formerly used for cattle. However, this is a time to watch cattle production closely m an endeavor to check it before the supply again reacts unfavorably on farm price. A study of past records and charts as well as current statistics will aid ma - terially m regulating production and stablizing price. 15

WHAT CAUSES THE FLUCTUATION IN THE PRICE OF HOGS AND HOW CAN IT BE REMEDIED? .More or less regu!ar intervals of fluctuation up and down m hog prices have been observed by all producers. The- system of hog production has often resulted m many farmers having large numbers ol s\vi.ne for sale when prices were low and small numbers for sale when prices were high. The uninformed have often blamed the packers and even statistics for this condition which the producer could remedy largely by steady production. Hog Production Runs m Four or Fire Year Cycles In general, hog production runs m four or five year cycles, two and a half years of increas - ing production and lower price levels and two and a halt years oE decreasing production and higher price levels. Price responds to production and price cycles arc caused by production cycles. Generally, a low production point m the cycle is met by high price. High prices stimulate production. More sows, are bred and increased market receipts are evident within a year. With good prices offered, production is maintained on a high or further increased level and lower prices result. Lower price discourages production until reduced production astain stimulates price and the cycle repeats itself. ■ Pljr Surveys Will Enable Fanners to Maintain Steadier Production and Price Past records show conclusively that the supply is the greatest factor determining price. The price paid for hogs is usua'.ly m proportion to the supply unless the factors affecting demand vary considerably. The first requisite m maintaining steady price is steady production. The lnt - ter is within the power of the producer. He must have a recurd of past production and price, the present production and future plans of producers. In fact, nearly all of the information needed is contained m the pig surveys that are made twice each year. The agricultural outlook issued early each year gives him valuable infoimation also. The spring' pig survey gives him the information :is to the size of the spring pig crop and tho breeding intentions for the fall crop. The December pig survey gives him the size of the fall pig' crop and the breeding intentions for the coming spring pig crop. (Note the records of the pig survey on the top of page 97.) The current reports issued m June and December gives the farmer the necessary information for changing his breeding plans sufficiently to adjust pro - duction more into line with future demand. How the Pig Surveys Are Made The pig surveys are conducted m cooperation with the Post Office Department. The pig survey asks for considerable detailed information on hogs upon the farm of the reporter. The June card calls for information on milk cows and sheep also. After the farmer fills out tho card it is returned to the mail box and collected by the rural carrier. He hands them to the postmaster who forwards them to the State and Federal Division of Agricultural Statistics. About 22,000 cards are mailed out m Nebraska. The returns are edited closely and those having errors or that are unsatisfactory for other reasons are thrown out. The balance are compiled and make up the sample from which the state estimate is made. It is essential that farmers report tho facts and that all farmers make a report if requested as that insures a more representative sample. These surveys must be accurate so that farmers can depend upon them as a guide to future production. Opposition comes from some who are not informed. They contend that it is no - body's business and that the packer receives the benefit. In the first place, the individual farm report is held stricOy confidential, ns only state totals are published. The progressive farmer makes it his business to know what all farmers of the country as a unit are producing and that Is what the pig surveys give. Packers have their own livestock reporting systems and furth - ermore they get the facts when the livestock comes to market. It is folly for anyone to think that he can hide the facts by refusing to report The facts concerning the hog industry will injure no one. The lack of the facts will pro - mote the old system of unbalanced supply which results m farmers having large numbers to sell when the price is low and small numbers to sell when the price is high. Past records show positively that the price depends upon the supply. Not only is the supply made known by the pig surveys, but also the plans for future production so that the producer is m a position to adjust his supply to meet future needs and is thereby enabled to maintain a Bteady supply and steady prices. This wi'.l do away largely with the old system of hog production cycles with the wide range of price fluctuation. All that is required is that all farmers report the facts on the pig survey cards when called upon and then follow the indications shown. Hog Outlook reports published and to be published by the U. S. Department of Agricu'.ture will help the farmer to make future production plans that will balanco demand. 31

potatoes: Relation between total production and u.s. farm price, 1920-1928 CENTS ' BUSHEL FARM PRICES ADJUSTED TO 1928 LE^EL OF FOOD PRICES . I . p 180 N^s— — : 160 V : ~~ ■ go I ' ' 1 J 1 1 1 2!^ 300 320 340 360 380 W0 i 420 440 460 480 U.S. PRODUCTION OF POTATOES -MILLION BUSHELS ' THE SUPPLY OF POTATOES IS THE LEADING FACTOR DETERMINING PRICE The above chart presents rather positive evidence that jhe supply of potatoes determines tile price. Note that in 192S when the production exceeded 4G0,0O0,O00 bushels that the price whs approximately 10.60 per bushel. Note also Mint In 1925 la-hen the production had dropped to nearly 320,000,000 bushels tlint the price was around jl.80 or three times as high in 1928, the year of unusually high production. Observe also, that in 1920 when the production was slightly below 400,000,000 bushels that the price was approximately $1.10 per bushel. Note the Otller years by following directly downward from the. dot to the production given in millions of bushels at the base of the chart and also from the dot to the extreme left where the corresponding price can be noted. It Is apparent that the price Is almost directly proportional to the quantity produced. What price would you expect If the crop xvns 360,000,000 bushels': Simply follow the' 360,000,000 bushel production line upward to the point that It Intersects the' heavy black lino and from tills point follow the line horizontally to the IH'l which shows ubout $1.40. Other factors beside supply affect the price, but the supply Is tjhe lending factor. CAN THE SUPPLY OF POTATOES BE ADJUSTED T<> BRING FAVORABLE PRICE To a certain extent, the production can be adjusted to meet demand and a favorable price, by avoiding greatly Increased or greatly reduced 'acreage. There has been a tendency in the past for farmers to plant heavily following n year of low production and high prices. This usually resulted in too large production and low prices. As a result of low prices again, a reduced acreage was plnnted the next year. This system gave a large supply to sell when prices were low and a small supply when prices were high. In general, the best policy, is to plant about the normal acreage each. year. At times, somo departure from normal planting Is desirable. The potato planting survey made In February each year offers considerable assistance in the way of adjusting acreage. This survey is made before the planting is started and gives the intended acreage for each state and for the country as a whole. If the intended acreage is considerably above- or consider - ably below the normal, farmers have an opportunity to change their acreage accordingly. During the past two or three years, some of the potato growers in the commercial- sec - tions have made n study of potato production and price and have adopted the policy of In - creasing their acreage following a year of large production and low price and decreasing their acreage following n year of low production and high price. This has had a tendency to more uniform production each year than formerly. W 'Other often plays a large part In production and while It may upset the l>est laid acreage plans, nevertheless, the exercise of care in avoiding too large or too small plantings ns shown by the planting intentions Burvey will help materially to obtain maximum financial returns. 72

Note the extremes of the quantity slaughtered anil the price. It you wHI draw a line - from the dot for the year 1922 perpendicular to the base or bottom line, you will note the slaughtered was between 8.500,000 and 9,000,000 pounds. Draw another line horizontally to the left margin of the chart and note the price was nearly $16 per 100 pounds. The slaughter was low m 1922 and the price high. Mq681,128 355,3761736 496,057,861 28 72 • Gross Cash Farm Income figures shown here and on the pages following are Intended to give the total cash receipts for farm products for the fiscal year ending June 30. Accord - ingly, all farm products consumed on the farm such as beef, pork, milk, butter and garden crops are omitted from this calculation. On the fiscal, year basis, crop sales are from the crop produced m the calendar year preceding the fiscal year date. All grain and crop values except those of barley and rye arc based on actual railway shipments; -values ot barley and rye being based on the percentage of the crop shipped out of the county m which grown. The value of crops sold locally for feeding purposes, is purposely omitted from these esti - mates as It is accounted for m the value received from the sale of livestock. Livestock val - ues are based upon actual market receipts from Nebraska, weighted on the basis of the average monthly prices which Nebraska farmers receive for each kind of livestock. Butter - fat and cream values arc derived from butterfat prices applied to figures of total manufac - ture as reported by dairy manufactures m the state. Poultry values are based on conserva - ■ tive estimates and the mid-month prices to the farmer. The following figures are undoubtedly conservative. Due to the fact that figures on the amount of grain sold direct to mills by farmers are not available, these values are not in - \ ■■ eluded; likewise the value of wliole milk sold m towns and cities and the vnlue of butter sold locally as well as that of several other items which cannot be closely estimated are not included In the following computation. 123

i • ■ .MM ? v BlHlliililJ!!C— . «~!EaB > j MBSBD - { . One of Nebraska's Farm Homes STATUS OF TUBERCULOSIS ERADICATION, 1925-1929 . - NoTHerds" No. of Estel> ~T. B. Year No. Herds No. Cattle Found Reactor lished Free _- Tested Tested Infected Cattle Co.Area3 Areas 1925 22,229 i 314,458 1,873 3,935 21 7 1926 29,778 i 393,872 2.408 4,023 30 U ■' 1927 29,416 ; 372,533 2,035 3,539 39 25 1928 27,923 327,911 2,000 3,411 43 31 1929 29,388 j 417,950 " 1,510 2,720 47 38 Steady progress has been maintained during the year, 1929, m Bovine Tuberculosis Eradication under the county area plan as shown by the foregoing maps and tabulation. ■ On January 1, 1923, 10 of Nebraska's counties bad been placed under supervision far tuberculosis eradication by the Bureau of Animal Industry. There were, m these 10. counties, a quarter million cattle and a halt million hogs, or 8.9% and 11.4% respectively, of the total. cattle and hog population of the state of Nebraska. Nn counties, however, had completed the test m order to be declared Mutinied Accredited Tuberculosis Free Areas at that time. Five years later, on January 1, 1930, 47 of the counties m Nebraska were established as areas of eradication and 3S of these had been declnred Modifled Accredited areas. At this time, 68% of all hogs and 47.6% of all cattle m Nebraska were m these areas established for eradication. Farmerß In these counties owned 1,396,105 head of cattle and 3,622,735 hbgß. Thirty-eight of these counties were accredited free areas, placing 2,623,421 hogs and 1,060,233 head of Nebraska's cattle In dißcaße-free territory. Farmers m those counties are entitled to receive the 10c per hundred weight premium, over market sales price, paid by all packers for hogs raised m a Tuberculosis-Free territory. According to the best available 1 records, packers paid farmers m the accredited areas a total of $2,093,924.66 since the work lias been In progress. A decrease of 42% is noted m the numbers of beef carcasses showing lesions of tuber - culosis coming under the inspection service of the United States Bureau of Animal Industry from January 1, 1925, to December 31, 1929, at the Omaha Market. Of the number of car - casses condemned during the Bame period there was an actual decrease of 1,120. For the fiscal yeara from July 1, 1924, to June 30, 1929, there was a decrease of 2.5% Id the number of swine carcasses showing lesions of tuberculosis on post-mortem inspection under federal supervision at Omaha and an actual decrease of 5,128 In the number of swine carcasses condemned. The above information is strikingly indicative of the benefits that have accrued thus far from the intensive cooperative campaign for the eradication of bovine tuberculosis. DR. C. H. HAYS, ■ ■ State Veterinarian. 131

NEBRASKA TEACHERS: This issue of the Nebraska Agricultural Statistics is dedicated to you. Since this is the year that the teaching of agriculture will receive special at - tention, this seems fitting and proper. This annual report has been used by the University, the State Normal schools, High schools and some of the country schools for several years in connection with the teaching of agriculture. Its use is endorsed by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction. This year, for the first time, a sufficient number of reports have been printed to furnish a copy for every school in the state, including the rural schools. It is suggested that every school retain this publication in the Library and that a request be made each year for future issues so as to maintain a complete file beginning with this issue. Within a period of slightly more than a half a century, Nebraska has be - come one of the leading agricultural states. Her greatest natural resource is her fertile soil. She has no forest, and so far, no appreciable quantity of minerals have been discovered! Yet, Nebraska's gross farm income is nearly $500,000,000 or more than ten, times the value of all gold mined- annually in the U. S. Latest figures on manufactures show a total value of $421,000,000. The interesting fact about the latter is that 55% of the manufactured products were derived from livestock and its products, and over 70% of the total manu - factured products were obtained from raw farm products. You cannot know Nebraska without knowing Nebraska agriculture. You are intersted in the progress of the state. Nebraska publishes one of the most complete reports of agricultural statistics of any state. You have a splendid opportunity to teach and instruct your students and pupils of the greatness of Nebraska. The reason Californians always boost their state is due to the fact that the pupils are taught at an early age in every school of the great advant - ages and high standing of that state. This is the* best kind of advertising and has aided largely in the rapid development of California. The high standing of Nebraska in agriculture is not fully appreciated. On the basis of staple crops and ■ livestock, excluding cotton and fruit crops, Ne - braska ranks at least third in agriculture and might lay claim to second place. The California plan of teaching the' state's agriculture in the schools will un - doubtedly do more to boost and develop our state than any other plan. .". ■' Agriculture needs more manufacturing to consume the raw farm products. With this will come increased population to consume the surplus food products of agriculture, water power development, irrigation projects and all other things essential to make Nebraska a leader in other industries besides ' agriculture. To attain this end, we must know Nebraska; know the great possibilities and - convey the information to the rest of the country in a way that will command attention. Statistics are essential to every successful endeavor. The State has at last recognized the need of more publicity by the establishment of a Publicity De - partment. The Division of Agricultural Statistics issues an annual report of Nebraska agriculture that contains three times the information contained in the average annual state report of agriculture. Knowledge of Nebraska's in - dustries is an important part of the education of our youth. It will stimulate an interest in the great field of possibilities in Nebraska that will bear fruit not only to the individual but to the development of the state. It will create a desire to remain here and encourage others to come. That helped California and it will help Nebraska. May we ask one favor in closing? The value of agricultural statistics is not appreciated by some farmers. Their value is best explained by the graphs and explanation on pages 14, 15, 31, 72 and 89. Will you study these and explain them to the older members of the class and then ask each one to take the report home and explain it to their parents if they are farmers. This will lead to a full appreciation as to how supply affects prices and how farmers can help themselves through a study of the supply shown by statistics by adjusting the supply to a certain extent. This favor will be of great benefit to the work. Thanks. . ,'••''. A. E. ANDERSON, Agricultural Statistician. 194
